docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I am astounded that the cost of psychotherapy is still being questioned (''Mental Illness Hits the Money Trail,'' Week in Review, June 6). Other health care needs in our society aren't evaluated in the same way. Although research shows that there is a connection between one's psychological state and one's interpersonal, work, school and health problems, many people still think that going to psychotherapy indicates weakness. A 1984 Rand study showed that 90 percent of people would not seek treatment even if it cost nothing.

docs.lead_paragraph: With Democrats stepping up the pressure for Congress to overhaul the managed-care system, several influential House Republicans introduced a package of legislation today that would increase the rights of patients but would not remove the high hurdles to suing managed-care providers. The bills put forward by Representatives Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania and John A. Boehner of Ohio won quick praise from Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, who called them common-sense proposals. His remarks suggested that the package was the approach the Republican leadership now favored, after months of searching for a party position on the issue.

docs.lead_paragraph: On April 21, a few hours before Ed Bradley's hourlong special report on abuses of children in the nation's largest chain of psychiatric hospitals was to be broadcast on CBS News's ''60 Minutes II,'' the chain sought a restraining order to block CBS from showing the report. A judge denied the request on the spot. Now the chain, Charter Behavioral Health Systems, is shutting down the hospital that was the focus of the ''60 Minutes II'' report, Charter Pines in Charlotte, N.C.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey's 27,000 unionized state employees have voted to authorize a strike if Gov. Christine Todd Whitman does not meet their demands to increase wages, freeze workers' health care costs and preserve the civil service seniority system, union officials announced today. With the current four-year contract expiring on June 30, the strike authorization won overwhelming support from state workers, who say they sacrificed during the state's lean fiscal years and are now entitled to share in New Jersey's billion-dollar budget surplus.

docs.lead_paragraph: The players union of the Women's National Basketball Association overwhelmingly ratified a labor contract last month, the first in women's professional team sports in the United States. The players won increased salaries, year-round health coverage, including maternity leave, a matching 401(k) program and limited job security for veterans. But many of the W.N.B.A. players agree that the process of insuring labor peace and jobs for the next four years was a lot rougher than they expected.

docs.lead_paragraph: Drug industry and insurance executives reacted with skepticism yesterday to reports that the White House was planning a new prescription-drug benefit for all elderly Americans. Under the proposal, Medicare recipients would pay $10 to $25 a month in addition to the current Medicare premium of $45.50, which does not cover drugs. Drug manufacturers said they did not believe Administration officials' assurances that the proposal would not lead to price controls on drugs. Alan F. Holmer, president of Pharma, a trade association, said the manufacturers favored Government support for drugs for the elderly but opposed a program that would be run by Medicare officials.

headline.main: Drug Makers Skeptical on Plan for Elderly

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will soon propose revamping the Medicare program to offer prescription drug coverage to all beneficiaries, and he will contend that such coverage can actually save money for the Government by reducing the need for hospital stays and nursing home care, Administration officials said today. The officials said the premium for the extra drug coverage would be less than $25 a month and could be as low as $10 a month.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Gores and Clintons shared a stage for two hours at the White House Conference on Mental Health today, and took turns interviewing people who have struggled with mental illness as a patient, parent or researcher. ''This is the last great stigma of the 20th century that we need to make sure ends here and now,'' said Tipper Gore, who ran the show and who recently revealed that she was clinically depressed after her son, Albert, nearly died when he was hit by a car in 1989 at age 6.
